pain_point: Answering service reps lack account-specific knowledge and require constant monitoring and retraining to handle calls properly.
Answering service misspells emails, phone numbers, and names in 40% of messages, and pricing is too high for low-volume callers.
Virtual receptionist routinely captures wrong phone numbers, addresses, and emails; customers hang up due to painful experience; would switch if an alternative existed.
Virtual receptionists pushed callers away by being unable to answer even simple questions like 'Do you have a website?' and couldn't pronounce the company name correctly.
Too many rotating receptionists means specific call handling instructions are frequently ignored; calls are forwarded when messages should be taken and vice versa.
Virtual receptionist ignored explicit instructions from business owner to screen a wrong-number call, wasting time and money during a busy event.
Per-minute billing feels opaque when a forwarded-to-voicemail call consumes 7 minutes of receptionist time with no documentation of why.
Virtual receptionist service is inconsistent: sometimes doesn't forward calls when available, sometimes misses appointments, gets names and emails wrong.
Receptionists ignore the script and put customers on hold despite instructions not to, and pricing is too high for a small business.
Service quality has declined and is now average, making the premium pricing no longer justified; actively shopping for alternatives.
Callers experience too many rings (up to 15) before the virtual receptionist picks up.
Virtual receptionist answers with wrong company name, doesn't capture requested information, and doesn't work with Google Voice.
Virtual receptionist failed to dispatch calls correctly during setup, causing lost jobs and significant revenue loss.
Too early to give a meaningful review after only 30 days of use.
Getting charged for solicitation calls that should be filtered, and outbound caller ID doesn't show company name/number through the app.
Inconsistent script adherence: some days call screening is spot on, other days receptionists seem not to have read the script.
Receptionist cannot differentiate between sales calls and actual vendors the business works with.
Many calls go unanswered and ring through to an automated system despite paying for live receptionist service.
Charged for calls to a recycled phone number unrelated to the business, billed over $30 for internal testing during an upgrade, and lost a day of customer calls due to flawed setup.
Expensive answering service does not consistently follow instructions despite premium pricing.
Receptionists have difficulty following call routing instructions and settings; errors persist even after multiple confirmations with support.
Small law firm's call instructions are not followed correctly and receptionists confuse two people with the same first name despite repeated reminders.
Ruby's pricing increased 42% over a few years, from $699/mo in 2011 to $1,279/mo in 2018, with annual increases making the service uncompetitive.
Patients report inconsistent experience with answering service; sometimes agents seem like they don't know what they're doing.
Billing seems questionable and messages contain errors after a few months of use.
Very long ring time before answering service picks up, risking lost customers.
Spent 2 hours over 3 calls trying to resolve an incorrect billing issue with answering service.
Answering service bill is 7-10x the expected budget; agents continually misspell names, emails, and addresses despite the critical importance of accuracy.
Caller experience varies greatly depending on which rep answers; the service is better than voicemail but far from ideal.
Answering service frequently doesn't pick up calls despite that being the core promise of the service.
Some call center agents don't follow the script and repeat the same mistakes despite corrections; owner is tired of repeating themselves.
Scripts need to be extremely simple because reps lack live training on each client; only top reps can handle nuanced information gathering, and escalation support is inadequate.
Operators don't follow the script and script changes are difficult to get implemented.
Customers complain about rude operators who leave incomplete or inaccurate information.
Answering service costs over $200/mo for 250 minutes, prices keep rising, and bot calls consume precious paid minutes with no automatic blocking.
Small business owner seeking pricing info and recommendations for answering services to handle contractor calls.
AI receptionist startup offering $14.99/mo plans with dedicated phone number, trying to undercut competitors charging $50-100/mo for similar features.
Virtual office provider promised phone answering but didn't deliver; implemented surprise per-minute charges that doubled the monthly bill even though calls were being forwarded elsewhere.
Solo attorney spends ~$1,200/mo on tech stack including answering service integrated with Lawmatics for intake, considers it worthwhile compared to hiring an employee.
Discussion about porting an 800 number between carriers after a call center change; technical VOIP issue not about receptionist service quality.
AI customer service creates frustration; prediction that having a real human answer phones will become a competitive differentiator in the next 15-20 years.
Lawyer rejects both answering services ('you can instantly tell and they suck') and AI voice assistants ('I hate robots and would never hire a lawyer who used them').
Smith.ai works well for solo lawyer with simple call routing: new clients get scheduled, existing clients get messages, urgent calls get transferred; but warns it won't scale for high call volumes.
General advice about law firm automation tools (practice management, CRM, paralegal hiring) with only a passing mention of receptionist/answering service as one option.
Happy Smith.ai customer (solo attorney scaling to 10-12 staff) praises human receptionists as flexible, affordable, and professional-sounding.
Detailed comparison of VOIP phone hardware (Cisco, Poly, Yealink) for office use; receptionist mentioned only in context of phone hardware preferences.
AI phone call handling for dental practices is promising for handling missed calls and waitlist fill-ups, but practice owners want to see it work first before committing.
Detailed technical advice about migrating a cloud PBX system with IP phones; no connection to receptionist or answering services.
Long-time Ruby Receptionist user canceled because it got too expensive.
Lawyer discusses Clio frustrations and states they don't see the need for a receptionist since they give clients their cell number.
Smith.ai employee explains their human-first and AI-first products, emphasizing that call data is never used for third-party LLM training, addressing lawyer confidentiality concerns.
Young agency entrepreneur asking for advice on selling AI chatbots and receptionists; no actual user experience or pain point with AI receptionist products.
General discussion about law firm voicemail practices and virtual office phone forwarding; not about receptionist or answering service quality.
All AI receptionists demoed so far haven't been good enough for prime time, but could serve as overflow/nights/weekends since they're still better than voicemail.
General advice about marketing a new law firm; mentions hiring a receptionist and SEO but not about virtual/AI receptionist services.
Advice about law firm workflow management; mentions designating a receptionist as file coordinator but not about virtual/AI receptionist services.
Personal story about transitioning a legal assistant into a hybrid receptionist/assistant role; about hiring human staff, not virtual/AI services.
Shared office receptionists handle phones for hundreds of businesses, causing things to get lost; wants something more trackable for intake.
Describes the ideal receptionist call flow: answer, get name, warm transfer to attorney, take message if unavailable, book consultation for new clients to prevent them calling the next firm.
Smith.ai works well as live reception for law firm; need to watch for repeat callers driving up costs but overall recommended with good customer support.
Discussion about hiring an in-house receptionist for a small law firm; about human staffing decisions, not virtual/AI services.
Review of LegalMatch lead generation service for attorneys; no connection to receptionist or answering services.
Mentions telling a physical office receptionist to block off conference room time; about in-person office use, not virtual/AI services.
Virtual receptionist vendor pitches services to a law firm: answering calls, setting appointments, routing calls, and handling after-hours coverage as advantages over hiring in-house.
Advice about hiring a human receptionist when expanding a family law practice; about staffing decisions, not virtual/AI services.
General advice about keeping law firm overhead low and possibly hiring a receptionist or executive assistant; not about virtual/AI services.
Personal career story about starting as a law firm receptionist 40 years ago; completely unrelated to virtual/AI receptionist services.
Comment clarifying that a virtual receptionist is a voice menu system, not AI; brief and tangential.
Discussion about law firm staffing structure (receptionist, intake, sales, attorneys); about internal hiring, not virtual/AI services.
Long personal legal story that incidentally mentions a law firm receptionist/secretary; entirely unrelated to virtual/AI receptionist services.
Advice for high school intern at a law firm; no connection to virtual/AI receptionist services.
Advice about considering a career in law; suggests taking a receptionist job at a law firm to shadow; completely unrelated to virtual/AI services.
Agency staffing and utilization discussion; mentions receptionist as a non-billable role example, not about virtual/AI services.
SmithAI receptionist service allows attorney and paralegal to stay off the phones and bill more, with reasonable pricing despite not being perfect.
Overview of call screening and virtual receptionist options for lawyers, listing Google Voice, OpenPhone, Ruby, Smith.ai, and Air.ai with pricing tiers.
Solo PI attorney launching a firm includes Smith.ai in their tech stack for receptionist services as part of startup costs.
Marketing consultant recommends Smith.ai or similar service for solo attorneys to ensure calls are answered and leads aren't lost.
Cloud-based answering service or call center solutions are more cost-effective and flexible than on-premise PBX systems for handling business calls.
Consultant advises new solo PI attorney to consider Ruby Receptionist or virtual assistant for initial intake to avoid missing time-sensitive leads while in court.
Solo attorney rejected an answering service that used high-pressure limited-time pricing tactics when he asked for a couple extra days to decide.
Discussion about agency sales tactics and cold-calling methods; no connection to receptionist or answering services.
Law firm associate discussing job offer details; mentions a couple of receptionists on staff but not about virtual/AI receptionist services.
Employee discussing their experience being hired as a receptionist at a law firm; about human employment, not virtual/AI services.
Solo PI attorney handling 70-80 cases is overwhelmed answering phones, attending court, and managing everything alone; considering first hire (receptionist vs paralegal vs associate).
VOIP technical advice about call queuing for a receptionist handling high call volume; about phone system setup, not virtual/AI receptionist services.
Comment about VOIP provider receptionist dashboards for call transfers; about phone system features, not virtual/AI receptionist services.
Agency sales discussion about getting past gatekeepers/receptionists on cold calls; receptionist mentioned only as an obstacle to reach decision makers.
Solo attorney describes using Zoom phone routed to mother-in-law as informal receptionist; about DIY setup, not virtual/AI receptionist services.
